(by 3 games) | date=October 22–29, 2008 | MVP = [[Cole Hamels]], Philadelphia | television = [[Major League Baseball on Fox|Fox]] | announcers = [[Joe Buck]], [[Tim McCarver]] | radio_network = [[Major League Baseball on ESPN Radio|ESPN]] | radio_announcers = [[Jon Miller]], [[Joe Morgan]] | umpires =[[Tim Welke]] (crew chief), [[Tim Tschida]], [[Jeff Kellogg]], [[Tom Hallion]], [[Kerwin Danley]], [[Fieldin Culbreth]]{{cite news|first=Steve|last=Gilbert|title=Umpires for World Series announced|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081021&content_id=3635021&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb|publisher=MLB.com|date= 2008-10-21|accessdate=2008-10-21}} | ALCS = [[Tampa Bay Rays]] over [[Boston Red Sox]] (4–3) | NLCS = [[Philadelphia Phillies]] over [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] (4–1) }} The '''2008 World Series''' was the 104th [[World Series]] between the [[American League|American]] and [[National League]]s for the championship of [[Major League Baseball]]. The [[Philadelphia Phillies]] as [[2008 National League Championship Series|champions of the National League]] and the [[Tampa Bay Rays]], as [[2008 American League Championship Series|American League champions]], competed to win four games out of a possible seven. The Series began on Wednesday, October 22, and (after weather delays had postponed the end of Game 5) concluded the following Wednesday, October 29. The American League's 4–3 win in the [[2008 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|2008 All-Star Game]] gave the Rays [[Home advantage|home field advantage]] for the series, meaning no more than three games would be played at the Phillies' stadium, [[Citizens Bank Park]].{{cite news |author= Associated Press|authorlink= Associated Press|title= Young caps marathon goodbye to Yankee Stadium with sac fly in 15th|url= http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=280715131|publisher= [[ESPN.com]]|date= 2008-07-15|accessdate=2008-09-17| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080914102247/http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=280715131| archivedate= 14 September 2008 | deadurl= no}} The Phillies won their second championship in their 126-year history, taking the series four games to one and brought the city of Philadelphia a championship after [[1983 NBA Finals|25 year]]s.{{cite news |first= Ken|last= Mandel|title=Octoberphest! Phillies win World Series|publisher=Major League Baseball|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650793&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher= [[MLB.com]]|date= 2008-10-30|accessdate=2008-12-22| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090201201208/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650793&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 1 February 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|title=WORLD CHAMPS!—28 years later, Phillies again are baseball's best|date=October 30, 2008|first=Phil|last=Sheridan|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|page=A1|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/phillies/20081030_Phil_Sheridan__Phillies_provide_a_season_of_memorable_moments.html?viewAll=y| accessdate= 28 February 2011 }} This was the first postseason series lost by a Major League Baseball team based in the state of Florida; previously, the Rays and [[Florida Marlins]] were 8–0 in post-season series.{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/|title=Playoff and World Series Statistics|work=Baseball-Reference.com|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=2009-06-17}}{{cite book|first=C. Alan|last=Joyce|title=The World Almanac and Book of Facts|edition=2009|location=New York|year=2008|isbn=978-1-60057-105-3|edition=paperback|pages=914–917}} The Philadelphia Phillies advanced to the World Series after defeating the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] and the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] in the National League's [[2008 National League Division Series|Divisional]] and [[2008 National League Championship Series|Championship Series]], respectively. The team won its position in the [[Major League Baseball postseason|playoffs]] after its second consecutive [[National League East]] title. This was the Phillies' first World Series appearance in fifteen years. The Tampa Bay Rays advanced to the World Series after defeating the [[Chicago White Sox]] and the [[Boston Red Sox]] in the American League's [[2008 American League Division Series|Division]] and [[2008 American League Championship Series|Championship Series]], respectively. The team earned its first trip to the postseason in franchise history after winning the [[American League East]] title, only one season after finishing in last place. Since each team had come first in its respective division during the [[Major League Baseball schedule|regular season]], this was the first Series since 2001 without a [[Major League Baseball#Postseason|wild-card team]]. ==Teams== ===Philadelphia Phillies=== [[File:Cole Hamels pitching 2010.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Philadelphia left-hander Cole Hamels, pictured here during the 2010 regular season, won Game 1 and was named the World Series MVP.]] {{main|2008 Philadelphia Phillies season}} Philadelphia opened the season by posting a winning record in the opening month of April. The team scored 60 runs over a five game span in late May and went 14–4 into the beginning of June. The team lost 9 of 11 games to end June, but came out of the [[2008 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star break]] with a 9–6 record following the midseason hiatus.{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/pi/tgl.cgi?t=b&team=PHI&year=2008|title=PHI 2008 Batting Gamelogs|publisher=BaseballReference.com|accessdate=2008-10-25}} The Phillies posted the best road record in the [[National League]], at 44–37.{{cite news |first= Jorge L.|last= Ortiz|title= Phillies assert themselves to take Game 1|url= http://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/playoffs/2008-10-23-asserting-phillies_N.htm|publisher= ''[[USA Today]]''|date= 2008-10-25|accessdate=2008-10-25}} Philadelphia traded [[List of baseball jargon (S)#sweep|sweeps]] with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] in August and went 13–3 in their last 16 games, to win [[National League East]] title for the second consecutive season.{{cite news |first= Gene|last= Cherry|first2=Ed|last2=Osmond|title= Phillies claim NL East but wildcard spot up for grabs|url= http://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSTRE48R09620080928?sp=true|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date= 2008-09-28|accessdate=2008-10-16}} They defeated the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] in the [[2008 National League Division Series|Division Series]] 3–1,{{cite news |author= Associated Press|authorlink= Associated Press|title= Burrell's blasts help send Phils past Brewers, into NLCS|url= http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=281005108 |publisher= [[ESPN.com]]|date= 2008-10-05|accessdate=2008-10-16| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081013090102/http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=281005108| archivedate= 13 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} and the Dodgers in the [[2008 National League Championship Series|Championship Series]], 4–1 to book their place in the 2008 Fall Classic.{{cite news |first= Ken|last= Mandel|title= Phils reach first World Series since '93|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/gameday_recap.jsp?ymd=20081013&content_id=3617454&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=phi|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-16|accessdate=2008-10-16| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081018201855/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/gameday_recap.jsp?ymd=20081013&content_id=3617454&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=phi| archivedate= 18 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} This was the Phillies' first World Series appearance in fifteen years.{{cite news |first=Jahmal|last=Corner|title=Phillies beat Dodgers to reach World Series|url= http://www.reuters.com/assets/print?aid=USTRE49F0VR20081016|agency= [[Reuters]]|date= 2008-10-16|accessdate=2008-10-16}} ===Tampa Bay Rays=== {{main|2008 Tampa Bay Rays season}} The Tampa Bay Rays also began the season with a winning record in the opening month of April.{{cite web|url= http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/TBR/2008_sched.shtml|title=Tampa Bay 2008 Game logs|publisher=BaseballReference.com|accessdate=2008-10-25| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080917165852/http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/TBR/2008_sched.shtml| archivedate= 17 September 2008 | deadurl= no}} The Rays became the first team since 1903 to have the league's best record on [[Memorial Day]] (the last Monday in May) after finishing in last place the previous season.{{cite news |author= Associated Press|authorlink= Associated Press|title= Kazmir Leads Rays Over Rangers 7-3 |url= http://www2.tbo.com/content/2008/may/26/kazmir-leads-rays-over-rangers-7-3/sports/|publisher= TampaBayOnline.com|date= 2008-05-26|accessdate=2008-11-10|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hDa3Uwns|archivedate=2009-06-01|deadurl=no}} The team went 16–10 in June, but lost seven consecutive games leading up to the All-Star break. In August, the Rays lost seven games to finish out the month with an overall record of 84–51. The team concluded the season, albeit with a 13–14 record in September, by winning the [[American League East]] title for the first time in franchise history.{{cite news |first= Gene|last= Cherry|coauthors= Sonia Oxley|title= Rays claim AL East title to cap turnaround|url= http://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSTRE48O9HL20080927|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date= 2008-09-27|accessdate=2008-09-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080930081055/http://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSTRE48O9HL20080927| archivedate= 30 September 2008 | deadurl= no}} The Rays beat the [[Chicago White Sox]] 3–1 in the [[2008 American League Division Series|American League Division Series]].{{cite news |author= Associated Press|authorlink= Associated Press|title= Upton's two homers set tone as Rays wrap up spot in ALCS|url= http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=281006104|publisher= [[ESPN.com]]|date= 2008-10-06|accessdate=2008-10-17| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081010131210/http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=281006104| archivedate= 10 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} In the [[2008 American League Championship Series|American League Championship Series]], Tampa Bay defeated the [[Boston Red Sox]] in seven games (4–3), to advance to their first World Series in franchise history.{{cite news |first= Ian|last= Browne|title= Sox's playoff run ends with loss to Rays|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081019&content_id=3631477&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-19|accessdate=2008-10-19}} {{Clear}} ==Game summaries== ===Game 1=== [[File:October 22, 2008 World Series Game 1.jpg|thumb|right|The teams on the field before Game 1]] Wednesday, October 22, 2008 at [[Tropicana Field]] in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]] {{Linescore| |Road='''Philadelphia'''|RoadAbr=PHI |R1=2|R2=0|R3=0|R4=1|R5=0|R6=0|R7=0|R8=0|R9=0|RR=3|RH=8|RE=1 |Home=Tampa Bay|HomeAbr=TB |H1=0|H2=0|H3=0|H4=1|H5=1|H6=0|H7=0|H8=0|H9=0|HR=2|HH=5|HE=1 |RSP=|HSP= |WP=[[Cole Hamels]] (1–0)|LP=[[Scott Kazmir]] (0–1)|SV=[[Brad Lidge]] (1) |RoadHR= [[Chase Utley]] (1)|HomeHR= [[Carl Crawford]] (1) }} The Philadelphia Phillies scored the first runs of the Series when [[Chase Utley]] hit a [[home run]] with [[Jayson Werth]] on base in the top of the first inning. The Phillies loaded the bases in the second inning, but were unable to score when [[Shane Victorino]] was thrown out at home plate by [[B. J. Upton]]. The Tampa Bay Rays loaded the bases in the bottom of the third inning; however, Upton grounded into an inning-ending [[double play]] and the score remained 2–0. The Phillies extended their lead when [[Carlos Ruiz (baseball)|Carlos Ruiz]] batted in Victorino in the fourth inning. In the bottom of the inning, a solo home run from [[Carl Crawford]] pulled the Rays within two runs. The Rays added their second run the following inning when a double by [[Akinori Iwamura]] scored [[Jason Bartlett (baseball)|Jason Bartlett]]. Tampa Bay starting pitcher [[Scott Kazmir]] was removed after six innings; [[J. P. Howell]] and [[Grant Balfour]] combined to shut out the Phillies for 1⅓ innings. [[Ryan Madson]] relieved Phillies' starter [[Cole Hamels]] in the eighth inning, pitching a single [[List of baseball jargon (P)#perfect inning|perfect inning]]. In the top of the ninth inning, two Phillies' runners reached base. Tampa Bay's [[Trever Miller]] was brought on and threw four pitches—striking out [[Ryan Howard]]—before he was relieved. Philadelphia stranded two runners, on second and third base, and entered the bottom of the ninth inning ahead by one run. Philadelphia's [[Brad Lidge]] struck out the first two batters he faced and retired the third batter to get the [[Save (baseball)|save]].{{cite news |title= World Series Game one|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_22_phimlb_tbamlb_1|work= Box Score|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-22|accessdate=2008-10-22| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081026045113/http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_22_phimlb_tbamlb_1| archivedate= 26 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} ===Game 2=== Thursday, October 23, 2008 at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Florida {{Linescore| |Road=Philadelphia|RoadAbr=PHI |R1=0|R2=0|R3=0|R4=0|R5=0|R6=0|R7=0|R8=1|R9=1|RR=2|RH=9|RE=2 |Home='''Tampa Bay'''|HomeAbr=TB |H1=2|H2=1|H3=0|H4=1|H5=0|H6=0|H7=0|H8=0|H9=x|HR=4|HH=7|HE=1 |WP=[[James Shields (baseball)|James Shields]] (1–0)|LP=[[Brett Myers]] (0–1)|SV= |RoadHR=[[Eric Bruntlett]] (1)|HomeHR= }} Tampa Bay scored the first runs of the game in the first inning when Akinori Iwamura and B. J. Upton scored on consecutive ground outs by [[Carlos Pena]] and [[Evan Longoria]] respectively. The following inning Upton singled, scoring [[Dioner Navarro]]. [[Rocco Baldelli]] attempted to score from second base, but was thrown out by right fielder Jayson Werth, keeping the Rays lead at 3–0. [[Cliff Floyd]] extended the Rays lead to four runs after leading off the bottom of the fourth inning with a single, advancing to third base, and scoring on a Jason Bartlett sacrifice bunt. Rays starter [[James Shields (baseball)|James Shields]] shut out the Phillies through 5⅔ innings, before being relieved by [[Dan Wheeler]] who pitched an additional scoreless inning. [[Eric Bruntlett]] hit a home run in the top of the eighth inning to bring the score to 4–1. The Phillies added a second run in the top of the ninth inning, but were unable to score any more runs; Tampa Bay's win tied the Series at one game apiece.{{cite web |title= World Series Game two |url= http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_23_phimlb_tbamlb_1 |work=Box Score |publisher=MLB.com |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2008-10-23| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081027021725/http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_23_phimlb_tbamlb_1| archivedate= 27 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} ===Game 3=== [[File:Ryan Howard3.jpg|thumb|right|Philadelphia first baseman Ryan Howard, pictured during 2007 spring training, hit his first home run of the postseason in Game 3.]] Saturday, October 25, 2008 at [[Citizens Bank Park]] in [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] {{Linescore| |Road=Tampa Bay|RoadAbr=TB |R1=0|R2=1|R3=0|R4=0|R5=0|R6=0|R7=2|R8=1|R9=0|RR=4|RH=6|RE=1 |Home='''Philadelphia'''|HomeAbr=PHI |H1=1|H2=1|H3=0|H4=0|H5=0|H6=2|H7=0|H8=0|H9=1|HR=5|HH=7|HE=1 |WP=[[J. C. Romero]] (1–0)|LP=[[J. P. Howell]] (0–1)|SV= |RoadHR=|HomeHR=[[Carlos Ruiz (baseball)|Carlos Ruiz]] (1), Chase Utley (2), [[Ryan Howard]] (1) }} The third game of the Series was delayed for an hour and 31 minutes because of rain.{{cite news |first= Mark|last= Newman|title= Rain doesn't dampen enthusiasm|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081025&content_id=3644569&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-25|accessdate=2008-10-25| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081027003254/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081025&content_id=3644569&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb| archivedate= 27 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} Country music star [[Tim McGraw]], son of Phillies reliever [[Tug McGraw]], spread his father's ashes on the pitching mound of Citizens Bank Park, prior to the game's start. The Phillies scored in the bottom of the first inning after [[Jimmy Rollins]] led off with a single and eventually scored when [[Chase Utley]] grounded out. In the next half inning, Tampa Bay's [[Carl Crawford]] doubled, stole third base and scored on a [[Gabe Gross]] sacrifice fly to center field. [[Carlos Ruiz (baseball)|Carlos Ruiz]] gave the Phillies their second lead of the night when he hit a solo home run in the bottom of the second inning. Starting pitchers [[Matt Garza]] and [[Jamie Moyer]] pitched six and 6⅓ innings respectively. The 2–1 score remained unchanged until the sixth inning when Chase Utley and [[Ryan Howard]] hit the 14th back-to-back home runs in World Series history.{{cite news |first=Alyson |last=Footer |title= Howard ends homerless drought|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081025&content_id=3643758&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-26|accessdate=2008-10-26| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081027003202/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081025&content_id=3643758&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb| archivedate= 27 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} Crawford scored his second run of the game in the top of the seventh inning when he was batted in by Gross again. [[Dioner Navarro]] continued the rally by scoring on a Jason Bartlett ground out—bringing the score to 4–3. In the top of the eighth inning, [[B.J. Upton]] led off with a single, stole second and third, and scored on a throwing error to tie the game. [[Eric Bruntlett]] was [[Hit by pitch|hit by a pitch]] leading off the bottom of the ninth, moved to second on a wild pitch and to third on a throwing error. Tampa Bay intentionally walked the next two batters to load the bases hoping to turn a triple-play and prevent a run from scoring, and brought in [[Ben Zobrist]] from right field to play as a fifth infielder in front of second base.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQyPTtnvHcA YouTube video of the Rays' five-man infield in the bottom of the ninth However, Bruntlett scored the winning run on Ruiz's 45-foot infield single, the first [[Walkoff home run|walk-off]] infield single in World Series history, giving the Phillies a 2–1 lead in the series.{{cite news |title= World Series Game three|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_25_tbamlb_phimlb_1|work= Box Score|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-25|accessdate=2008-10-25| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081029033530/http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_25_tbamlb_phimlb_1| archivedate= 29 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} ===Game 4=== Sunday, October 26, 2008 at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania {{Linescore| |Road=Tampa Bay|RoadAbr=TB |R1=0|R2=0|R3=0|R4=1|R5=1|R6=0|R7=0|R8=0|R9=0|RR=2|RH=5|RE=2 |Home='''Philadelphia'''|HomeAbr=PHI |H1=1|H2=0|H3=1|H4=3|H5=1|H6=0|H7=0|H8=4|H9=x|HR=10|HH=12|HE=1 |WP=[[Joe Blanton]] (1–0)|LP=[[Andy Sonnanstine]] (0–1)|SV= |RoadHR=Carl Crawford (2), [[Eric Hinske]] (1)|HomeHR=Ryan Howard 2 (3), Joe Blanton (1), [[Jayson Werth]] (1) }} Philadelphia took a 1–0 lead in the bottom of the first inning, as [[Jimmy Rollins]] led off with a double and scored when [[Pat Burrell]] later walked with the bases loaded. The Phillies doubled their lead in the third inning when [[Chase Utley]] reached base on a fielding error and scored on [[Pedro Feliz]]'s single. The Rays scored their first run when Carl Crawford hit a solo home run in the top of the fourth inning. Ryan Howard's three-run home run in the bottom of the inning brought the score to 5–1. Tampa Bay's [[Eric Hinske]] hit a [[Pinch hitter|pinch-hit]] home run to bring the Rays within three runs, but Phillies pitcher Joe Blanton responded with a home run of his own to re-extend the lead to four; it was the first time a pitcher hit a home run since [[Ken Holtzman]] in the fourth game of the [[1974 World Series#Game 4|1974 Fall Classic]].{{cite news |first= Matthew|last= Leach|title= Blanton picks right time for first homer|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081026&content_id=3646950&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-26|accessdate=2008-10-26}} Blanton pitched six innings, giving up two runs on four hits to acquire his first win of the Series. Jayson Werth hit a two-run home run in the eighth inning—the Phillies third of the game—to bring the score to 8–2. Later in the inning Ryan Howard's second home run, and fifth RBI, increased the Phillies lead to eight runs. Philadelphia's four [[relief pitcher]]s combined for three shutout innings, giving up one hit.{{cite web|title= World Series Game four|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_26_tbamlb_phimlb_1|work= Box Score|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-26|accessdate=2008-10-26| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081027163410/http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_26_tbamlb_phimlb_1| archivedate= 27 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} Due to the late completion of the previous game, Games 3 and 4 each ended on the same calendar day. ===Game 5=== [[File:Evan Longoria Cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Tampa Bay third baseman Evan Longoria, pictured during the 2008 regular season, got his first hit in Game 5.]] Monday, October 27, 2008 (started) and Wednesday, October 29 (completed) at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania {{Linescore| |Road=Tampa Bay|RoadAbr=TB |R1=0|R2=0|R3=0|R4=1|R5=0|R6=1|R7=1|R8=0|R9=0|RR=3|RH=10|RE=0 |Home='''Philadelphia'''|HomeAbr=PHI |H1=2|H2=0|H3=0|H4=0|H5=0|H6=1|H7=1|H8=0|H9=x|HR=4|HH=8|HE=1 |RSP=|HSP= |WP=[[J.C. Romero]] (2–0)|LP=[[J.P. Howell]] (0–2)|SV=Brad Lidge (2) |RoadHR=Rocco Baldelli (1)|HomeHR= }} Philadelphia scored in the first inning for the third consecutive game, taking a 2–0 lead when Shane Victorino batted in Jayson Werth and Chase Utley. Tampa Bay cut the lead in half in the fourth inning; Carlos Peña doubled and was batted in on [[Evan Longoria]]'s single, both players' first hits of the Series. The Rays then tied the game in the sixth inning when B. J. Upton scored from second base on a Peña single.{{cite news |title= World Series Game five|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_27_tbamlb_phimlb_1|work= Box Score|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-27|accessdate=2008-10-27| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081031063722/http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/ps/y2008/boxscore.jsp?gid=2008_10_27_tbamlb_phimlb_1| archivedate= 31 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} The game was suspended after the top of the sixth inning due to rain, making it the first game in World Series history not to be played through to completion or declared a tie.{{cite news |first= Bryan|last= Hoch|title= In a first, World Series game suspended|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081027&content_id=3649539&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-28|accessdate=2008-10-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081028203316/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081027&content_id=3649539&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 28 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} After the game was suspended, umpiring crew chief [[Tim Tschida]] told reporters that he and his crew ordered the players off the field because the wind and rain threatened to make the game "comical."{{cite news |first= Gene|last= Wojciechowski|title= Selig made correct call in suspending Game 5|url= http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/columns/story?columnist=wojciechowski_gene&id=3668142&sportCat=mlb|publisher= ESPN.com|date= 2008-10-27|accessdate=2008-10-30| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081031103756/http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/columns/story?columnist=wojciechowski_gene&id=3668142&sportCat=mlb| archivedate= 31 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} Chase Utley agreed, saying that by the middle of the sixth inning, "the infield was basically underwater." Rain continued to fall in Philadelphia on Tuesday, further postponing the game to Wednesday, October 29. The game resumed with the Phillies batting in the bottom of the sixth inning. Pinch hitter [[Geoff Jenkins]] led off with a double and was bunted to third by Rollins. Jayson Werth then batted in Jenkins to take the lead for the Phillies, 3–2. In the top of the seventh inning, Rocco Baldelli re-tied the game at three runs with a solo home run. Later in the inning, Utley faked a throw to first, then threw Bartlett out at home for the third out in a play later described as having saved the Series for the Phillies.{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/phillies/20090213_How_the_defining_play_unfolded_for_the_Phillies.html|title=How the defining play unfolded for the Phillies|date=2009-02-13|first=Frank|last=Fitzpatrick|first2=Jim|last2=Salisbury|accessdate=2009-03-13|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hDa2iEFQ|archivedate=2009-06-01|deadurl=no}} In the bottom of the seventh, [[Pat Burrell]] led off with a double. Eric Bruntlett, pinch-running for Burrell, scored on a single by Pedro Feliz to put the Phillies up by a run again, 4–3. In the top of the ninth, [[Brad Lidge]] gave up a single and a stolen base, but was able to strike out [[Eric Hinske]] to win the World Series for the Phillies. ====Implications of the suspension==== [[File:2008 world series rain delay.JPG|thumb|right|The grounds crew covers the field with a tarpaulin during the Game 5 rain delay.]] Under normal conditions, games are considered to be official games after five innings, or four and a half if the home team is leading at that point. However, post-season games are operated by the [[Commissioner of Baseball|Commissioner's]] Office, thus are subject to the Commissioner's discretion of how to handle the scheduling of the games. So, with rain in the forecast for Philadelphia, Commissioner [[Bud Selig]] informed both the Rays and the Phillies management before the game began that a team would not be allowed to clinch the Series in a rain-shortened game.{{cite news |first= Larry|last= Fine|coauthors= John O'Brien|title= Suspension leaves World Series in the balance|url= http://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSN2646794520081028?feedType=RSS&feedName=sportsNews&sp=true|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date= 2008-10-28|accessdate=2008-10-28}} Because of the rainfall, Game 5 was suspended after the top of the sixth inning. Rain continued to fall in Philadelphia on Tuesday, October 28, and the game ultimately resumed on Wednesday, October 29, at Citizens Bank Park.{{cite news|first= Bryan|last= Hoch|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650918&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title= Game 5 will not resume on Tuesday|date=2008-10-28|accessdate=2008-10-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081029181417/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650918&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 29 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} Official MLB records will show that even though the game was finished on October 29, the game was officially played two days earlier, and was completed on that date. This was the first game in World Series history to be [[suspended game|suspended]].{{cite web| url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650971&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb | title=FAQs on the suspended Game 5 | accessdate=2008-10-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081029181422/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650971&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 29 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} There had been three [[Tie (draw)|tied games]] in the history of the World Series: [[1907 World Series|1907]], [[1912 World Series|1912]], and [[1922 World Series|1922]], all of them called due to darkness. In general, no ties would be needed under modern rules, which provide for suspension of a tied game and resumption of it at the next possible date. Weather has caused numerous delays and postponements in Series history (notable postponements beforehand coming in 1911, 1962, 1975, 1986, 1996 and 2006), but never any suspended games before 2008. Although not officially a suspended game, the most notorious postponement of a World Series due to natural events was the [[1989 World Series]] in which the start of Game 3 was delayed ten days, the longest in World Series history, due to the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake|Loma Prieta earthquake]] striking the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. Several Nevada sports betting agencies treated the suspended game as a completed game and a win for the Phillies on Monday, October 27. Under Nevada house rules, the final score of a baseball game is determined by reverting to the last completed full inning, and the Phillies led 2–1 at the end of the fifth inning. Game 5 side bets on Philadelphia were paid off while bets on totals and [[sports betting#Types of bets|run-line bets]] were refunded.{{cite web| url=http://www.lvrj.com/sports/33433179.html | title= Sports books pay as if Phillies won | accessdate=2008-10-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081029073327/http://www.lvrj.com/sports/33433179.html| archivedate= 29 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} During the following offseason, Selig's interpretation of the rules became codified, as the 30 Major League Baseball club owners approved a rule change stipulating that all "postseason games and games added to the regular season to determine qualifiers for the postseason" become [[suspended game]]s if they are called before nine innings are played, regardless of whether the game would otherwise qualify as an [[official game]], or the score at the time the game is called. The game is resumed when conditions permit at the same location from the point of suspension.{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20090115&content_id=3745318&vkey=pr_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=Ownership approves two major rules amendments|date=2009-01-15|work=MLB.com|publisher=Major League Baseball|accessdate=2009-02-02| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090121182633/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20090115&content_id=3745318&vkey=pr_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 21 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==Summary== The Philadelphia Phillies (2008 champions of the [[National League]]) defeated the Tampa Bay Rays ([[American League]] champions) by four games to one, played in [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]] and [[Philadelphia]] from Wednesday, October 22 to Wednesday, October 29, 2008. ===Series overview=== {| class="wikitable" |-style="background: #e3e3e3;" !|Game||colspan="2"|Score (visitors listed first)||Date(s)||Location||Attendance |- |align=center|1||Philadelphia Phillies – 3|| Tampa Bay Rays – 2||October 22||rowspan="2"|[[Tropicana Field]],

|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hbsvHRv5|archivedate=2009-06-17|deadurl=no}} }} ==Weather conditions== Games 3 and 5 of the World Series were delayed by rain storms in Philadelphia, with the start of Game 3 on Saturday, October 25 being delayed an hour and 31 minutes (with that game ending at 1:47 am [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] Sunday, October 26). Game 5, begun on Monday, October 27, was suspended after 5½ innings and resumed Wednesday, October 29.{{cite news |first= Bryan|last= Hoch|title= Game 5 will not resume on Tuesday|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650918&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-28|accessdate=2008-10-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081029181417/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081028&content_id=3650918&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 29 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} Wet weather which affected Game 5 continued into Tuesday in the Philadelphia area, as Major League Baseball officials studied radar data to determine when Game 5 of the World Series would continue under conditions deemed "appropriate." Up to this point, there had never been a rain-shortened game in Series history, and this was the first suspension. As a result, had it been necessary to play them, Games 6 and 7 in St. Petersburg, originally scheduled for October 29 and October 30, were postponed until a later date. With temperatures plummeting to the mid-40s Fahrenheit and a cold rain falling at Citizens Bank Park, some of the Phillies and Rays players opted for an "[[Elmer Fudd]]" look, wearing specially made caps with built-in ear flaps.{{cite news |author='Duk |title= 'Elmer Fudd' caps become hip during cold and wet World Series |url= http://ca.sports.yahoo.com/mlb/blog/big_league_stew/post/-Elmer-Fudd-caps-become-hip-during-cold-and-wet?urn=mlb,117761|publisher= Yahoo! Sports|date= 2008-10-27|accessdate=2008-10-28}} The caps, manufactured by [[New Era Cap Company|New Era]], were introduced during this year's [[spring training]] but were not used on the field until Game 5. New Era also supplied regular ball caps to both teams, which some players continued to wear despite the cold weather. ==Broadcasting== [[File:Phillies-Parade Harry-K crop.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Harry Kalas]], pictured at the World Series parade, called the World Series as a Phillies broadcaster, and got to call a Phillies World Series win, something he couldn't do in 1980, while his son, Todd, called the series for the Rays.]] The games were televised on [[Major League Baseball on Fox|Fox]] in the [[United States]] with [[Joe Buck]] and [[Tim McCarver]] (himself a former [[List of Philadelphia Phillies broadcasters|Phillies broadcaster]]) as booth announcers{{cite web |url= http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/schedule/ps.jsp|title= Tentative 2008 MLB Postseason Schedule|accessdate=2008-09-16 |work= World Series|publisher= MLB.com| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080914075014/http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/schedule/ps.jsp| archivedate= 14 September 2008 | deadurl= no}} and [[Chris Myers]] and [[Ken Rosenthal]] as field reporters.[http://www.salon.com/sports/daily/feature/2008/10/23/game_1_notes/index.html?source=rss&aim=/sports/daily/feature Tim McCarver's flying start]. Salon.com. October 23, 2008. [[Jeanne Zelasko]] hosted the pre-game and post-game show with [[Kevin Kennedy (baseball)|Kevin Kennedy]] and [[Mark Grace]] (Games 1, 2) or [[Eric Karros]] (Games 3, 4, 5). [[Fox Sports en Español]] did the simulcast of the Series in [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]] with [[Angel Torres]], Miguel Morales and Cos Villa behind the microphones. Fox's broadcasts were also streamed online at [[MLB.com]]. On radio, the Series was broadcast nationally by [[Major League Baseball on ESPN Radio|ESPN Radio]] with [[Jon Miller]] and [[Joe Morgan]] announcing, and a Spanish broadcast on [[ESPN Deportes Radio]]. Locally, [[Dave Wills (sportscaster)|Dave Wills]], [[Andy Freed]], [[Dewayne Staats]] and [[Joe Magrane]] called the Series in [[English language|English]] for the Rays on [[WHNZ|WHNZ-AM]] in Tampa, with Ricardo Tavaras and Enrique Oliu working the Spanish broadcast on St. Petersburg's [[WGES (AM)|WGES-AM]]. [[Harry Kalas]], [[Scott Franzke]], [[Larry Andersen]], and [[Chris Wheeler]] called the Phillies' English broadcasts on [[WPHT|WPHT-AM]] in Philadelphia, with Spanish announcers Danny Martinez, Bill Kulik and Juan Ramos on [[WDAS (AM)|WUBA]]. Following their contractual obligations, the non-[[flagship (broadcasting)|flagship]] stations on the teams' radio networks carried the ESPN Radio broadcasts. MLB.com also carried the local radio broadcasts for online streaming, while [[XM Satellite Radio]] aired the local and national feeds to its subscribers. For Harry Kalas, this series brought together a father and son calling the series for different teams, with his son, [[Todd Kalas|Todd]], calling the Series in English for the Rays.{{cite news|title=In 78 Minutes, Not Much to See or Say|date=October 30, 2008|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|newspaper=New York Times|page=B17|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/30/sports/baseball/30sandomir.html?_r=1&pagewanted=print| accessdate= 14 October 2010 }} For international viewers, MLB International televised the game with commentators [[Rick Sutcliffe]] and [[Dave O'Brien (sportscaster)|Dave O'Brien]]. This feed was also carried to U.S. service personnel stationed around the globe via the [[American Forces Network]]. Game 1 was watched by 10.1 million viewers in the United States; Commissioner [[Bud Selig]] stated he was satisfied with the ratings.{{cite news |first= Barry M.|last= Bloom|title= Selig pleased with Game 1 ratings|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081023&content_id=3640727&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnerId=rss_mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-23|accessdate=2008-10-25}} Overall viewership was 25% lower than the previous World Series.{{cite news |first= Barry M.|last= Bloom|title= Game 4 draws Series' highest ratings|url= http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081027&content_id=3649354&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|publisher= MLB.com|date= 2008-10-27|accessdate=2008-10-28| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081031063747/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081027&content_id=3649354&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb| archivedate= 31 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} The overall national [[Nielsen rating]] for the five games was 8.4, tied with the [[2010 World Series]] for the event's lowest-ever TV rating.[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/ws/wstv.shtml World Series Television Ratings Breakdown] This World Series win had significance for McCarver and Harry Kalas. Both were Phillies broadcasters in {{wsy|1980}}, but neither one could call the final out.{{harvnb|Miller|2010|pages=169–173}} McCarver was a backup commentator for ''[[Major League Baseball Game of the Week|Game of the Week]]'' on [[Major League Baseball on NBC|NBC]], but he was not part of the broadcast team that called the final out. For Kalas, MLB radio-broadcasting regulations forbade local stations from producing live coverage of World Series games, instead forcing them to air the national [[Major League Baseball on CBS Radio|CBS Radio]] feed of the games. Philadelphia fans were so outraged about this afterward that they started a letter-writing campaign to the [[Commissioner of Baseball|Commissioner's Office]], demanding a change to the rule. The [[1981 World Series|following year]], MLB amended its broadcasting contracts to allow World Series teams' flagship radio stations to air the games with local announcers, due at least in part to this outcry from Philadelphia fans. In 2008, both called the Phillies' World Series win. ==Umpiring== [[File:Phillies board.JPG|thumb|right|The scoreboard at Citizens Bank Park immediately following Game 5]] In Game 2, home plate umpire [[Kerwin Danley]] appealed a call to the first base umpire after calling strike three; the first base umpire called ball four to award the Rays' [[Rocco Baldelli]] a walk. Baldelli indicated that the calls did not come up in the locker room, and he did not believe they had an effect on the results.{{cite news |title=Umpires in Spotlight For the Wrong Reasons |last=Robinson |first=Joshua |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/sports/baseball/28baseball.html?_r=1&em&oref=slogin |date=2008-10-28|accessdate=2008-11-01|newspaper=New York Times| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081030015030/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/sports/baseball/28baseball.html?_r=1&em&oref=slogin| archivedate= 30 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} In Game 3, Phillies' pitcher [[Jamie Moyer]] threw the ball to [[Ryan Howard]] to force out the Rays' [[Carl Crawford]] at first base, despite umpire [[Tom Hallion]] calling Crawford safe in the game.{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=3667915&type=story |title=Umpires admit second missed World Series call in as many games |author=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN |date=2008-10-27 |accessdate=2008-11-01}} In Game 4, [[Evan Longoria]] tagged Rollins at third base, though umpire [[Tim Welke]] had ruled Rollins safe. The league admitted these errors between Games 4 and 5. ==Impact and aftermath== ===Phillies=== [[File:Philadelphia Phillies Barack Obama.jpg|thumb|right|President [[Barack Obama]] meets with the 2008 World Series champion Philadelphia Phillies at the [[White House]]—May 15, 2009]] The Phillies' second World Series championship brought about a series of firsts, not just for them, but for Philadelphia. In winning their first championship since {{wsy|1980}}, the Phillies brought the city of [[Sports in Philadelphia|Philadelphia]] its first major professional sports championship since the [[Philadelphia 76ers|76ers]] swept the [[1983 NBA Finals]]. In summing up the firsts and given how long the city's sports fans have waited, Phillies President [[David Montgomery (baseball)|David Montgomery]] said that "our first name is Philadelphia," and he and manager [[Charlie Manuel]] dedicated the championship to the city of Philadelphia and the fans.{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/video/play.jsp?mid=200810293653581|title=Phillies receive trophy|date=October 29, 2008|accessdate=February 19, 2011|work=MLB.com}} Manuel also dedicated the championship to his mother, who died on the day of Game 2 of the [[2008 National League Championship Series|NLCS]].{{cite web|title=Thrilla in Phila: Game 5 unforgettable|url=http://www.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081029&content_id=3653812&vkey=news_phi&fext=.jsp&c_id=phi|date=October 30, 2008|accessdate=February 21, 2011|first=Mark|last=Newman|work=MLB.com|publisher=phillies.com}} Phil Sheridan of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' said that the 25 years without a championship "helped define this city as a sports town for way too long. It was long enough to turn passion too often to anger. Maybe this championship will turn the vinegar back into wine," and said that the fans "waited forever and a day." On [[Halloween]], October 31, approximately two million lined [[Broad Street (Philadelphia)|Broad Street]] for a ticker-tape parade,{{cite news|quote=Some in the news media guessed two million, about the same number long tied to Flyers parades in '[[1974 Stanley Cup Finals|74]] and '[[1975 Stanley Cup Finals|75]], and more than the current population of Philly.|title=A party for, oh, 2 million of their closest friends|date=November 1, 2008|first=Derrick|last=Nunnally|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|page=F2}} making it the largest gathering for a championship parade in Philadelphia since the [[Philadelphia Flyers|Flyers]] won the [[1974 Stanley Cup Finals]].{{cite news|quote=In the annals of Philadelphia sports parades, the biggest crowd turned out for the 1974 celebration of the Flyers' Stanley Cup. More than two million fans flocked to Broad Street.|title=Parade for the Champs; Noon High: Million-plus expected at celebration|date=October 31, 2008|first=Jennifer|last=Lin|first2=Allison|last2=Steele|coauthors=Dwight Ott|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|page=A1}} This parade had significance for Phillies Pitcher [[Jamie Moyer]] and Phillies Broadcaster [[Harry Kalas]], as they both were at the 1980 parade.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/sports/Watch_Phillies_Speak_From_the_Parade_of_Champions.html|title=Watch: Phillies Speak From the Parade of Champions|date=November 1, 2008|first=Dan|last=Stamm|work=NBCPhiladelphia.com|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} Moyer grew up in the Philadelphia area as a Phillies fan and whose childhood hero was [[Steve Carlton]], a member of the 1980 team, and whom he won against in his first Major League start.{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/nl/phillies/2007-07-02-Loser-Phillies_N.htm|title=Phillies are No. 1 in loss column|date=July 16, 2007|first=Mel|last=Antonen|newspaper=USA Today|quote=Current Phillies starter Jamie Moyer grew up in Philadephia...In 1986, as a member of the Cubs, Moyer beat the Phillies and his boyhood hero, Steve Carlton...for his first big-league win.| accessdate= 25 January 2011 }} He was at both of the Phillies World Series parades, skipping school to attend in 1980, and as a pitcher in 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2008Oct31/0,4675,BBNPhilliesParade,00.html|title=Fans roar as Phillies parade through city|date=October 31, 2008|first=Michael|last=Rubinkam|agency=Associated Press|work=FOXNews.com|accessdate=January 25, 2011}} Kalas was at both parades, as a broadcaster for the Phillies. When comparing to the parade to the one in 1980, he told [[WCAU|WCAU-TV]] that "this is bigger...the biggest I've ever seen." In 2010, Philadelphia sports fans picked both of the Phillies' World Series wins as the two greatest moments in Philadelphia sports, picking the 2008 championship as the greatest moment.{{cite news|title=Fans pick 2008 World Series as top Philadelphia sports moment|date=May 6, 2010|first=Mark|last=Kram|newspaper=Philadelphia Daily News|url=http://articles.philly.com/2010-05-06/news/24959019_1_philadelphia-fans-philadelphia-sports-phillies| accessdate= 4 March 2011 }} The Phillies returned to the World Series in {{wsy|2009}}, the first defending champion to return to the Series since the [[2001 New York Yankees season|2001 New York Yankees]]. During [[2009 Major League Baseball season|that season]] they finished first in the National League East with a 93–69 mark, and eliminated the [[2009 Colorado Rockies season|Rockies]] and the [[2009 Los Angeles Dodgers season|Dodgers]] in the NL playoffs. They would lose to the Yankees in six games. ===Rays=== For the Rays, at the same time the ticker-tape parade went down Broad Street in Philadelphia, thousands of Rays' fans attended a rally at Straub Park in [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]], celebrating their 2008 season.{{cite web|url=http://tampabay.rays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081031&content_id=3658769&vkey=news_tb&fext=.jsp&c_id=tb|title=Rays' fans celebrate at rally|date=October 31, 2008|accessdate=March 4, 2011|first=Brittany|last=Ghiroli|work=TampabayRays.MLB.com|publisher=Major League Baseball}} Mayor [[Rick Baker (mayor)|Rick Baker]] said that the rally "really needed to be done. There was so much demand in the community. They didn't win the World Series but they won the AL. And we want to celebrate that and thank them." He and Tampa Mayor [[Pam Iorio]] addressed the fans during the rally. Though the Rays missed the playoffs in 2009, they earned a winning record of 84–78, placing them third behind the Red Sox and eventual champion Yankees. ==References== ;Inline citations {{reflist|2}} ;Bibliography *{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Randy|title=Harry the K: The Remarkable Life of Harry Kalas|year=2010|publisher=Running Press|location=Philadelphia, PA|isbn=0-7624-3896-7}} ==External links== {{Portal|Baseball}} {{Commons category|2008 World Series}} {{WSExtLinks|year=2008}} *[http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/playoffs2008/series?series=phitam ESPN - MLB Playoffs - 2008 World Series - Tampa Bay Rays vs. Philadelphia Phillies] *[http://www.mlb.com/phi/history/championship08.jsp Phillies Championship page] {{Navboxes|list1= {{2008 MLB Playoffs navbox}} {{2008 MLB season by team}} {{World Series}} {{2008 Philadelphia Phillies}} {{Philadelphia Phillies}} {{Tampa Bay Rays}} {{Major League Baseball on Fox}} {{Major League Baseball on ESPN Radio}} }} [[Category:World Series]] [[Category:2008 Major League Baseball season|World Series]] [[Category:Tampa Bay Rays postseason]] [[Category:Philadelphia Phillies postseason]] {{Link GA|es}} [[de:World Series 2008]] [[es:Serie Mundial de béisbol de 2008]] [[fr:Série mondiale 2008]] [[ja:2008年のワールドシリーズ]] [[ko:2008년 월드 시리즈]] [[zh:2008年世界大賽]]
